reviews.review: Canon o no canon, he ahí el dilema.
La mejor expansion de half-life sin duda, y con alta dificultad a comparacion de blue shift y el half-life base XD

Half life opposing force is an extension to the original Half life so with that it has some big shoes to fill and to live up to the outstanding game witch is half life one. And I am happy to say that its is. And maybe it maybe even better in the way it is paced Gearbox has some how managed to keep the original feel and flow of half life intact with out no compromises. You play as Adrian Shephard one of corporals/soldiers sent to Black Mesa to eliminate the Xen invaders and to silence the witnesses, especially the scientist named Gorden Freeman, as part of a classified mission.

The game is much more shorter than the original Half life it could only take you 2 hours if you know what you are doing. But I feel like this benefits the game as there were a lot of annoying chapters in the original Half life that seems out dated and hinders an overall amazing game i'm looking at you on a rail. 

Overall if you like the half life series and what to play something that is in the same vane Opposing Force is a good option.

Es un buen juego en la saga Half-Life, aunque su campaña y su final deja algunos cabos sueltos, como la aparición de la Raza X, o la bomba termonuclear en Black Mesa. No estoy del todo seguro si es Canon o no, pero logra su cometido: expandir la historia principal de una manera disfrutable. AUNQUE, no es del todo necesaria para entender la trama de la saga, más bien es prescindible.

Half Life: Opposing Forces is an interesting take on what happens during the Black Mesa incident, unlike in Blue Shift where the game provides no new input or new weaponry, Opposing Forces follows a completely different character on a completely different side with new weapons that we’re not completely used to using.

Following Shepard is great, seeing a new perspective on why the army did what they did to Gordon and the science team is interesting. Usually these types of games, where you play as the villains of the previous game, try to make the ‘bad guys’ look good since they either don’t have a choice or simply don’t know the full story, but I admire that this game just goes with the fact that they did not care and only you the player can truly act like a human being.

It’s nice to see the G-Man actually do stuff, as we’re all used to him just creeping around Black Mesa following Gordon in both games doing nothing but standing still and walking away - but here, in this game, we actually get to see him being this character they showcased him to be in Half Life, a being that works for someone who has higher power over everything else.

The enivronment annd bosses remind me of the encounters Gordon has in the original game and the way they’re executed is just plain old fun - I also just wanna remind you that although they feel similar, they aren’t (something that the later game, Half Life: Blue Shift fails to do). Overall, the game is worth playing through and it’s just as fun as the original Half Life…

Взгляд с другой стороны катострофы на "Блэк Меза", со стороны 22-летнего солдата HECU, которые были посланы убить всех учённых и свидетелй. К несчатью, самолёт расбивается и Шепарда и других военных повсюду коплекса соберают учённые и естественно помогают вылечить их раны и повреждения. Шепард и кучка солдат благодарят учённых и бегут на сигнал радио-вещанния от остальных военных, которые собираются эвакуироваться. Появляются наёмные солдаты, которым дали распоряжение взорвать "Блэк Мезу" и убить и тех и этих. Одним словом месиво 10/10. Для 1999 отличный сюжет.

A nice alternate perspective on the original game. And just goes to show the bad guys aren't always THE bad guys.

Yeah, I don't know.

It's a game that I enjoy because of how it plays, I like the gunplay and the set pieces but it also hasn't aged well in a multitude of different aspects.

For one, the difficulty is extremely unbalanced, this is an absurdly challenging game at times independently on whether you're playing the game on normal, hard, or easy.

Then there's the level design and some of the game's pacing, a lot of the times I would rely on either the antiquated a.i. to open paths for me, or alternatively, I would get shot by them because I would accidentally get in their crossfires and they weren't smart enough to stop shooting at me, nor did the developers programmed the game to make me invulnerable to the a.i. companion's shots.

Then there was this really obnoxious bug/glitch around the middle of the game where I just couldn't change my weapons, I tried everything I could, exit the game, exit to the menu, save and load, quick save and load, use cheat codes to noclip to a more open area in case that had something to do with it, then I even tried to spawn an rpg, it worked, but it still wouldn't let me change my weapons, I had to reload a save file from 10 minutes since then, then I could progress through the game; but after a while it got boring.

Generally I just sort of remained either frustrated with this game, or disappointed with it because I got bored after a while.

In some cases the path to progress were also fairly cryptic or outright frustrating to play through.

There's some platforming in some Xen areas near the half of the game, those got fairly annoying because of how "floaty" my character felt, at times it would be as if the developers had just deliberately placed the platforms just far enough for you to fell as soon as you ALMOST reached the edge.

Crouch jumping didn't help.

Then there was this part near the end where I just didn't know where to go next, this games are fairly linear for the most part, but here I couldn't for the life of me; find the freaking pathway to progress.

Eventually I did, turns out I had to jump through the broken window of one such elevator, something that I don't think I've ever had to do in any other Half Life game, even in the first game where you have to do a similar thing, you do it by slamming the window pane of the elevator door that's closest to the ground, and the game gives you a ton of hints in its design to let you know this is what you're supposed to do, it even places the crowbar right next to that elevator door.

Overall I just thought it was a cool concept for a game, specially a Half Life game, given that you're playing from the perspective of one of the soldiers that gets to Black Mesa facility; sadly it didn't pay off at the end though, I couldn't bring myself to even finish it.
good half life game that shows a perspective of a different person during the Black Mesa Incident

«Opposing Force» is a really good example of that when expansions were like a whole game.

This game parallels the original «Half-Life» storyline, but here we follow the events from the side of «HECU» grunt Adrian Shephard.
